awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: A Biotic Inventory of Terrestrial Vertebrates, Spiders, and Haemosporidian Parasites of Sulawesi, Indonesia
awd_abstract_narration:
The Indonesian island of Sulawesi is unusually rich in species and therefore is an important location for biodiversity discovery. This research project will inventory terrestrial vertebrates (amphibians, reptiles, birds and mammals), spiders, and vertebrate parasites of this large tropical island. Field teams composed of specialists on each of these taxonomic groups will survey 10 major mountains on Sulawesi over the course of five field seasons. By thoroughly sampling this island now while some forest remains fully intact and depositing these collections in natural history museums, the raw materials (specimens) supporting the study of tropical diversification will be made available to this and future generations of biological researchers. This project includes training of undergraduate and graduate students, postdocs, and technicians from US and Indonesian research institutions in biotic survey research. Senior Indonesian scientists will aid US researchers in a collaborative analysis of specimens. The research team will organize two workshops primarily oriented around molecular genetic data collection and analysis, including high-throughput sequence data, and corresponding population genetic, phylogenetic, and biogeographical analysis. 

Sulawesi is characterized by a highly endemic biota, resulting from its large size, geographic setting, long period of isolation from all other land masses, and complex tectonic history. The island exhibits substantial topographical relief, with vast areas over 1000 m above sea level, 20 summits greater than 2500 m in height, and six summits above 3000 m. It probably has never been connected to the more proximate Sunda continental shelf to its west, nor with the more distant Sahul Shelf (New Guinea, Australia, and their land-bridge islands) to its east, and thus has been isolated for its entire history of 20-25 million years. Sulawesi is a composite island composed of at least five paleo-islands that were distantly separated from one another for several million years before merging more or less simultaneously between 10 and 5 million years ago. The composite nature of the island has been strongly implicated in the process of in situ species diversification on Sulawesi. Field sites for biotic survey work were selected to allow thorough sampling of the four arms of Sulawesi as well as its Central Core. A major focus of the program will be sampling along elevational transects on the largest mountains of each Area of Endemism, thereby enabling transects that reach >2500 m in elevation. None of the focal taxa targeted here have been sampled adequately from high elevation sites. The scientific value of the proposed field efforts are considerable and fall broadly into the following themes: (1) documentation of biodiversity, including species and their distributions, evolutionary and population genetic relationships and affinities, and the chronology and geological context of species and community diversification, (2) conservation biology, including documentation of disease outbreak and response, invasive species, and extinction, and (3) understanding of interesting evolutionary processes, including adaptive radiation, hybridization, ecological opportunity, and the genetic basis of biological innovation.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA, THE

por.por_cntn:
We performed biodiversity discovery on the tropical Indonesian island of Sulawesi, the 11th largest island in the world. Sulawesi has been isolated for its entire ~25 million year history, and its native biota consequently originated via overwater dispersal. In addition to its great age and continuous isolation, Sulawesi experienced a tremendously complex tectonic history, having arose first as a single smaller island, passed through a transitory period as new islands formed creating an archipelago of up to 13 significant islands, with these islands ultimately enlarging to amalgamate into a single bizarrely K-shaped mega-island. Sulawesi is now a composite of multiple paleo-islands that merged beginning about 8 million years ago. As a result, Sulawesi has at least seven primary areas of endemism, each with species found nowhere else in the world. Although substantial biogeographic research has focused on regional diversification on Sulawesi, less attention has been paid to the tremendous topographical relief of Sulawesi and the potential role of mountain building in driving speciation on this island. Our project was aimed specifically at addressing this latter gap in understanding.

Sulawesi is a mountainous island, with 6 summits higher than 3000m and 20 summits greater than 2500m in elevation. Mountains provide dramatically stratified climatic regimes and thus are often occupied by elevationally-stratified species. We targeted eight mountains and two islands for elevational transect sampling of amphibians, reptiles, birds, mammals, arthropods, and haemosporidian blood parasites. The eight surveyed mountains were Latimojong, Bawakaraeng, Katopasa, Torompupu, Dako, Ilomata, Ambang, and Klabat. We also surveyed two offshore islands, Sangihe and Karakelang. This fieldwork not only supported species discovery, but also analyses aimed at elucidating diversification mechanisms on Sulawesi across areas of endemism as well as across elevational gradients.

We performed fieldwork over five field seasons with a four-year gap between the fourth (2019) and fifth (2023) field seasons because Indonesia was closed to foreign researchers during the Covid-19 pandemic. Our fieldwork was highly productive. We collected 2627 mammal specimens, 1171 bird specimens, 3036 amphibian and reptile specimens, and 42,980 arthropod specimens, including more than 10,000 individual spider specimens. This is a vast underestimate of the arthropod sampling because the Indonesian arthropod team members separately catalogued their own collections, including all samples obtained from jointly-conducted passive trapping using Winkler and Malaise traps; thus, the true number of arthropods sampled must have been well over 100,000 specimens. Our research has resulted in the discovery of hundreds, if not thousands, of new species, only a fraction of which have yet been worked up as we await the export of our last collecting effort (much of our research requires genetic analysis). Nevertheless, we report large numbers of new species. For example, Sulawesi currently has six named Limnonectes fanged frog species but we have 43 species in our collection. There are 11 described species of Sphenomorphus and Tytthoscincus scincid lizards but our phylogenomic and population genomic analyses indicate that we likely have at least 70 species in our collection. Similarly, there are four described Oreophryne crossfrogs but we have at least 22 species in our collection, and so on. For spiders and other arthropods, the number of undescribed species in our collection is likely immense. Anna Holmquist, as part of her dissertation research, used a mini-barcoding approach to assess spider species diversity on just four of the mountains we sampled. Her analysis suggests 508 species despite that there are only 278 species of spiders known from all of Sulawesi, indicating a massive current underestimate of spider diversity on the island.

 

In addition to our extensive specimen collections, this program resulted in substantial opportunities for training and professional development at multiple levels. For example, we provided field opportunities for 52 Indonesian curators, professors, junior staff, and students at the Indonesian national museum (Museum Zoologicum Bogoriense), at one university in Bogor (IPB), and at four universities on Sulawesi. Of these participants, 31 of 52 joined multiple expeditions. From the US and Australia, we brought one undergraduate and 19 graduate students (five of whom successfully defended PhD dissertations based on research made possible by this grant), one postdoctoral fellow, and seven professors and/or senior curators. Everyone participating in these expeditions gained invaluable experience in remote expeditionary fieldwork, were exposed to SE Asian biodiversity, saw and experienced the diverse strategies employed by field biologists in support of their research, and made dozens of connections with scientists who work in Asia. Our team also provided seminars at local universities after each expedition, which was a wonderful way to introduce local students to the incredible biodiversity that characterizes Sulawesi, while also allowing our team leaders to make additional contacts with local scientists. The publications that are being generated as part of this project (24 so far and many more in progress) provide additional opportunities for professional development for everyone involved, and especially for student participants.

 


Last Modified: 07/17/2024
Modified by: Jimmy A Mcguire
